Literature Review: The large-Nc limit of Quantum Chromodynamics (QCD) has been a subject of interest in the field of nuclear physics, particularly in the context of two-nucleon (NN) interactions. The NN interaction is a fundamental aspect of nuclear physics, describing the strong nuclear force that holds nucleons together. In this review, we will discuss the implications of the large-Nc limit on the NN interaction, its ordering, and potential applications to few-nucleon interactions, including those from weak and beyond the Standard Model (BSM) interactions, as well as two-nucleon external currents. We will also discuss the caveats and potential pitfalls associated with the large-Nc ordering and its limitations in other contexts where data are less readily available.
